title: The Wolfe makes your laptop VR-ready on the cheap – and it's this week's featured Kickstarter | Trusted Reviews
description:

main](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-

**Every week, we scour Kickstarter, Indiegogo and more to find the best
crowdfunding projects around so you know which ones to consider backing – and
what to definitely avoid.**

This week’s pick is [The
Wolfe](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/thewolfe/the-wolfe-supercharge-
your-laptop?ref=category_recommended), a device that gives your laptop the
same processing power as a desktop computer. And our ‘one to avoid’ is an
Apple knock-off that’ll have Cupertino’s lawyers rubbing their hands with
glee.

**Related:[The Ticwatch 2 is a smartwatch like no other – featured
Kickstarter](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/why-you-should-crowdfund-the-
ticwatch-2-the-smartwatch-you-can-tickle)**

## What is The Wolfe?

It’s a box containing more processing power than you can shake a mouse at.
Plug it into your laptop, and you can play high-end games, experience virtual
reality, and do any high-speed rendering as if you were playing with the power
of a pricey desktop PC.

![the wolfe
work](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

Technically, it’s what’s known as a GPU (Graphics Processing Unit). This is
the part that focusses on gaming and 3D rendering, as opposed to the CPU
(Central Processing Unit), which is more the “brains” of your computer.

It comes in two versions. The Wolfe uses an [Nvidia GTX
950](https://www.trustedreviews.com/nvidia-geforce-gtx-950-review) GPU – that
has 768 cores working at 1,024MHz, giving it a computing power of 1.57
TeraFlops. And The Wolfe Pro runs on an [Nvidia GTX
970](https://www.trustedreviews.com/nvidia-geforce-gtx-970-review), giving you
1,664 cores operating at 1,050MHz, resulting in a whopping 3.49 TeraFlops.
That’s as much power as a top-end [Mac
Pro](https://www.trustedreviews.com/apple-mac-pro-review), and that’s on top
of your laptop’s existing GPU. Beefy.

The Wolfe works with both Windows and macOS, so you should be able to use it
whether you’re a laptop or MacBook owner.

## Why is it interesting?

It basically turns your laptop into two computers. When you need the extra
grunt, plug it in and it’ll give you the power of a desktop. But, if you nip
out and only need to work on a document, just leave it at home, taking only
your feather-light laptop with you.

![the wolfe
bag](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

Hey presto! Your laptop has desktop power when you need it, and is a light and
portable computer when you don’t.

Of course you can take it with you if you like. It’s a little smaller than a
shoebox, and weighs 908g, which is less than a MacBook Air. So it should fit
in your bag without too much trouble.

It also makes virtual reality a lot more accessible. Until now, VR has only
been possible on a [pricey desktop
computer](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/can-i-run-the-htc-vive), but
plug The Wolfe into your laptop, and it has the grunt necessary to render
virtual worlds. Sling a headset in your bag, and you’ve got VR experiences on
the go.

![EZ Gif](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)  
**Related:[We’ve backed the Superbook on Kickstarter – here’s why you should
too](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/turn-your-phone-into-a-laptop-
with-the-superbook-our-kickstarter-pick-of-the-week)**

It’ll also be a boon to anyone demoing their VR software. Instead of making
people come to them, or making sure they have a sufficiently powerful PC, they
can take VR to any office.

With VR headsets still prohibitively expensive, this could be the shot in the
arm that virtual reality needs to go mainstream.

The Wolfe can also help your laptop play the latest games, without requiring
you to replace it with a pricey and bulky gaming-specific model

. And it lets creative professionals using graphics programs work faster and
more efficiently than ever.

## What are the challenges?

As ever with crowdfunding sites, you support a project at your own risk.
There’s no guarantee a project will succeed, or even get off the ground. So
bear that in mind before you cough up your dosh.

![the wolfe
vr](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

Manufacturing any product is tricky, but Wolfepack has sought to minimise the
risk by partnering with Dragon Innovation – the firm that helped bring the
[Pebble](https://www.trustedreviews.com/pebble-time-round-review) smartwatch
and [Makerbot](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/makerbot-releases-android-
app-for-controlling-3d-printers) 3D printer to market. Dragon has helped asses
production costs and economies of scale, so – fingers crossed – it should all
go smoothly.

**Related:[Why you should fund a System Shock
remaster](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/system-shock-this-week-s-
featured-kickstarter-crowdfunding-project)**

However, Wolfepack does note that high demand could cause delays. Seeing as
the project has smashed its funding goal many times over, it could be a victim
of its own success.

## Is there anything similar available?

Very similar to The Wolfe is the Razer Core. Allowing you to use full-length,
double-wide PCIe desktop graphics cards, Razer’s external graphics enclosure
attaches to your laptop via Thunerbolt 3 (USB Type-C).

![Razer
Core](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

You have to buy the graphics card separately from the enclosure itself, but it
comes with additional I/O ports such as 4 USB 3.0 connections and Ethernet.
Plus, it features a little handle, which makes it a bit easier to carry
around.

It’ll only work with Thunderbolt 3 ports however, so it makes Mac
compatibility a bit tricky, though the expected MacBook Pro update could
introduce the connection. The Wolfe is available in Thunderbolt 2 and 3
flavours, though future versions will only use Thunderbolt 3.

## Should I crowdfund this?

If you like the idea of VR on the go, better gaming on your laptop and more
power to play with, then yes.

**Read more:[Worst crowdfunding
campaigns](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/worst-crowdfunding-
campaigns-kickstarter-indiegogo)**

![the wolfe in
situ](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

The $399 (£302) early birds are sold out, but you can pick one up for $449
(£340), or $599 (£453) for the Wolfe Pro. That’s a hell of a lot cheaper than
some of the top-end gaming laptops and PCs you’ll need to invest in if you
want to run the [Oculus Rift](https://www.trustedreviews.com/oculus-rift-
review) or [HTC Vive](https://www.trustedreviews.com/htc-vive-review).

Shipping will start in March (or February for anyone lucky enough to have
nabbed an early bird).

## And one to avoid this week…

[Pear Inc. Start-up Company](https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pear-inc-
startup-company#/). Does that logo look familiar? We thought so. Pear’s motto
is: “The only thing that is permanent if [sic] change. Our focus is to create
tools for the mind that advance human kind.” Such as? It doesn’t say. And what
has it done in the past? Again, there’s no mention.

We assume it’s a joke. But even so, it looks like a lawsuit waiting to happen.
